subject: Re: [junit] HOW TO ASK QUESTIONS ON THIS GROUP
msgSnippet: One problem that develops in many of these lists is that the greatest volume of posts is from people who are new to the API/product/language being supported
messageBody:
One problem that develops in many of these lists is that the greatest
volume of posts is from people who are new to the API/product/language
being supported and therefore new to the list. Courtesy would demand that
the new user spend time exploring the site, the documentation, and so
forth, plus perhaps monitor the list for a bit before posting to it.
However, I have noticed two things, both of which surprise me in different
ways.

1) Some people simply aren't courteous and really expect people to do
their work for them. Many of these people seem to succeed at this in their
workplace and, when required to do something new, extend that practice to
the net. Over time, however, I've discovered that the number of people in
this category is actually not large and that many people actually belong
in the 2nd category.

2) Some people simply don't have the first clue how to be courteous in
this environment. Typically they are either students or professionals who
have suddenly had new demands placed on them and are not self-starters.
They may try to figure things out at first, but simply have no context to
start. As they may already be frustrated and resentful, they give up
quickly, especially if they are not strong in english.

The utter lack of context in this second group has surprised me greatly
and I think it is hard for many in the OS community to grasp. For example,
I still commonly run into junior programmers who don't know what a "FAQ"
is or what a "list archive" is for. They see these words on the site but
don't know what to do with them.

Most projects are organized similarly. I've been around the internet
enough that when I look at a new project I pretty much go through things
in a set order and know exactly what to look for. If the things I need are
not there, I will most likely just skip it and go back to FreshMeat for a
different, similar project. Most people who answer questions on this list
are the same. It is hard for me to believe that people still lack these
skills, but they really do.

Even if someone does know what these things are, I have watched people
flounder for hours with a search engine or list archive becuase they don't
have good research skills and don't know what to search for or they don't
know how to work through the hits and figure out which ones are really
relevant to their issues. Again, this is especially true for people who
are not strong in english.

I am at a loss for how to deal with this effectively and would welcome
discussion. One thing that I have seen have some positive effect is a FAQ
posting at regular intervals (e.g. weekly) to the list. This posting
should be targetted at this second category of individuals, carefully
explaining where to find docs, tutorials, how to search the archives,
etc., as well as making a plain statement to the first category that they
are expected to do their own homework. We might even consider making this
post multi-language. The FAQ should also always be the first message a new
subscriber receives (replacing the current "Welcome to JUnit" message.
This adds a little clutter to the list, but, with a clear subject line
it's easy to avoid and may reduce clutter overall.

On Mon, 15 Oct 2001, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> Ladies and Gentlemen:
>
> I am frankly quite concerned with the quality of the exchanges going on here
> in the last several weeks. It appears that many people think there are
> "magic formulas" for working with JUnit. As a result, they ask silly
> questions like, "How do I test an EJB with JUnit????" The people who know
> the answer get so tired of writing, "Search this list. Try it. What are you
> having trouble testing?" that they simply stop responding. As a result,
> questions are not being answered.
>
> I would like to ask everyone on this list to ask specific, pointed
> questions, with sample code, if at all possible. Instead of "How to I test
> an EJB????", how about, "I did X, Y and Z to test EJBs using JUnit, but it's
> too slow. Any tips for increasing speed? Here is a sample EJB tets case..."?
>
> If you really don't know how to do X, try searching the web first. Try
> searching this list's archives next. If that does not get you going, then by
> all means, ask a specific, pointed question.
>
> Please, folks! I don't want to start ignoring this list because its readers
> show no initiative.
>
> JBR.
